Report and Recommendation of the President  
to the Board of Directors
 
 
Project Number: 50200-001 
October 2016 
 
 
 
 
Proposed Loan  
Triconboston Consulting Corporation (Private) 
Limited 
Triconboston Wind Power Project 
 
(Pakistan)
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This RRP contains information that is subject to exceptions to disclosure set forth in ADB’s Public 
Communications Policy 2011. Recipients should therefore not disclose its content to third parties, 
except in connection with the performance of their official duties. Upon Board approval, ADB will 
make publicly available an abbreviated version of this RRP, which will exclude confidential 
business information and ADB’s assessment of project or transaction risk.

CURRENCY EQUIVALENTS 
(as of 15 September 2016)

$1.00  =  PRs104.58

BAFL  –  Bank Alfalah Limited

EPA  –  energy purchase agreement 
EPC  –  engineering, procurement, and construction

IPP  –  independent power producer

NSO  –  nonsovereign operations 
NTDC  –  National Transmission and Despatch Company Limited 
O&M  –  operation and maintenance 
STML  –  Sapphire Textile Mills Limited 
TBCC  –  Triconboston Consulting Corporation (Private) Limited 
 
WEIGHTS AND MEASURES 
km  –  kilometer 
kWh  –  kilowatt-hour  
m  –  meter 
MW  –  megawatt 
 
NOTES 
(i)  The fiscal year (FY) of the Government of Pakistan ends on 30 June. “FY” before a 
calendar year denotes the year in which the fiscal year ends, e.g., FY2016 ends on 
30 June 2016. 
(ii)  In this report, “$” refers to US dollars.

1 
 
I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan of 
up to $75 million to the Triconboston Consulting Corporation (Private) Limited (TBCC) for the 
Triconboston Wind Power Project in Pakistan.1 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
A.  Project Identification and Description 
2.  Project identification. Acute energy deficit has been one of the major constraints to 
Pakistan’s economic growth. To ensure a sustainable energy supply, the Government of Pakistan 
has  launched  some  initiatives  to  promote  private  sector  participation  in  the  country’s 
infrastructure. As part of these efforts, several energy policies were introduced and have resulted 
in significant investment from the private sector. As of FY2015, private sector investments owned 
and operated 11,574 megawatts (MW), or 46.2% of the country’s installed power capacity.2 TBCC 
is a special purpose vehicle set up to develop, construct, commission, and operate three adjacent 
49.7 MW wind power plants in southern Sindh Province; once commissioned, the 149.2 MW 
facility will be the county’s largest wind farm to date. The sponsors, Sapphire Textile Mills Limited 
(STML) and Bank Alfalah Limited (BAFL), have a right to possession of almost 3,800 acres for 
the project, which has been leased on a long-term basis to TBCC by the Government of Sindh. 
The project will be developed under the Renewable Energy Power Policy of 2006, under which 
the Asian Development Bank (ADB) has already financed three wind power independent power 
producers (IPPs), and will benefit from the 20-year upfront wind feed-in-tariff (FiT) set by the 
National Electric Power and Regulatory Authority (NEPRA), Pakistan’s power sector regulator. 
 
3.  STML and BAFL formed a partnership in 2012 to jointly develop renewable energy 
projects in Pakistan. The first project of STML and BAFL was a 52.8 MW wind farm in Jhimpir 
Sindh, Sapphire Wind Power Company Limited (SWPCL) that achieved commercial operations 
in 2015.3 After successfully completing the project and leveraging the experience gained in its 
development, STML and BAFL decided to develop a pipeline of future renewable (wind and solar) 
energy projects in Pakistan and, as a part of that strategy, acquired TBCC to develop a 150 MW 
wind farm in the same vicinity as SWPCL. STML and BAFL approached ADB in late 2015 for 
financing given (i) ADB’s record of supporting the country’s first three wind-based IPPs—Zorlu 
Enerji Power Project and Foundation Energy I and II Projects;4 (ii) the large long-tenor project 
debt requirement; (iii) earlier discussions between ADB and STML and BAFL in which ADB 
indicated it was interested in supporting renewable energy projects and/or initiatives in Pakistan; 
and (iv) the project’s need for foreign financing, given that the majority of costs will be dollar-
denominated. 
 
4.  Project design. The project comprises the design, construction, and operation and 
maintenance (O&M) of three 50 MW wind power plants (and associated infrastructure) adjacent 
to each other in Jhimpir, about 100 kilometers (km) northeast of Karachi in Sindh Province.  
(Confidential information redacted under para. 97(v) of ADB’s Public Communications Policy) 
                                                
1  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
2  National Electric Power Regulatory Authority. 2016. State of the Industry Report 2015. Islamabad. 
3  ADB’s Private Sector Operations Department was approached to finance this project but was unable to do so 
because of country exposure limit constraints given Pakistan’s downgrade by Moody’s in 2011. 
4  ADB. 2010. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Loan to the Zorlu 
Enerji Power Project in Islamic Republic of Pakistan. Manila; ADB. 2011. Report and Recommendation of the 
President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Partial Credit Guarantees for the Foundation Wind Energy I and II 
Projects in Pakistan. Manila.

2       
 
5.  The borrower, Sapphire Textile Mills Limited and Bank Alfalah Limited. TBCC is a 
special purpose vehicle that has the right to develop three wind power plants of 50 MW each 
(collectively the project). TBCC is owned by (i) the Sapphire Group, a leading local conglomerate 
with experience in thermal and renewable power project development, including a successfully 
commissioned wind farm in the same wind corridor as the project; and (ii) BAFL, Pakistan’s sixth 
largest  bank.  ADB  conducted  integrity  due  diligence  following  its  Integrity  Due  Diligence 
Guidelines for Nonsovereign Operations.5 No significant or potentially significant integrity risks 
were found. 
 
6.  (Confidential information redacted under para. 97(v) of ADB’s Public Communications 
Policy).  Founded  in  1940, the  Sapphire Group—a  network  of family  owned  and managed 
companies—is one of Pakistan’s largest conglomerates, with investments in textiles, power, dairy, 
and real estate development. (Confidential information redacted under para. 97(v) of ADB’s Public 
Communications Policy). 
 
7.  Sapphire Fibres Limited was incorporated in 1979 and is publicly listed. It is a vertically 
integrated textile unit manufacturing cotton yarn, fabrics, and garments. (Confidential information 
redacted under para. 97(v) of ADB’s Public Communications Policy). 
 
8.  BAFL is a publicly listed commercial bank incorporated in Pakistan in 1997, and has 653 
branches covering 225 cities in Pakistan and seven cities overseas. (Confidential information 
redacted under para. 97(v) of ADB’s Public Communications Policy). It has a 6.5% market share 
(based on total deposits) and holds a notable position among the domestic private banks. BAFL 
has presence in Afghanistan, Bahrain, Bangladesh, and the United Arab Emirates and is listed 
on the Pakistan Stock Exchange. In December 2014, the International Finance Corporation 
acquired a 15% shareholding in BAFL to allow BAFL to focus more on small- and medium-sized 
enterprises, agricultural industries, and sustainable energy financing. 
 
B.  Development Impacts, Outcome, and Outputs 
9.  Impacts. The impacts will be (i) ensured access to affordable, reliable, sustainable, and 
modern energy for all, set by the Sustainable Development Goals; (ii) improved power supply in 
Pakistan, and (iii) improved power generation mix through investment by the private sector. The 
project  will  help  alleviate  Pakistan’s  severe  power  shortages,  which  hamper  the  country’s 
economic growth and efforts to reduce poverty. The project’s successful implementation will also 
foster confidence among investors and lenders, and promote further private sector investment in 
renewable energy and power. 
 
10.  Outcome. The outcome will be an increased supply of renewable energy from wind 
sources. The project will generate an additional 520 gigawatt-hours of electricity annually by using 
wind, and the tariff for project-supplied electricity will be lower than that for plants using imported 
fuel and other renewable energy sources such as wind and solar. The project will also avoid 
greenhouse gas emissions of about 380,000 tons of carbon dioxide equivalent per year. The 
project will contribute to the local economy by creating 35 full-time jobs during operations. 
 
11.   Outputs. The output will be the net additional installed power generation capacity of 150 
MW, which is equivalent to about 3% of the country’s power shortfall. The project will contribute 
                                                
5  ADB. 2015 Integrity Due Diligence Guidelines for Nonsovereign Operations. Manila.

3 
to the local economy by purchasing $31 million in local goods and services and creating 300 jobs 
during construction. 
 
C.  Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations 
12.  Consistency with ADB strategy and country strategy. The project is consistent with 
ADB’s  Midterm  Review  of  Strategy  2020  for  inclusive  economic  growth,  environmentally 
sustainable growth, private sector development and operations, environment and climate change 
adaptation and mitigation, and infrastructure development.6 ADB’s support for the project is in line 
with its Pakistan country partnership strategy, 2015–2019, which emphasizes energy sector 
development, private sector participation in infrastructure development, and ADB’s private sector 
operations’  expansion  in  the  energy  sector.7 The  project  is  a  logical  outcome  of  ADB’s 
development and reform efforts in Pakistan’s energy sector, which have  promoted a well-
regulated, market-oriented power industry, particularly as the country faces challenges attracting 
commercial financing. Energy infrastructure has featured prominently in ADB’s private sector 
operations in Pakistan. 
 
13.  Consistency with sector strategy and relevant ADB operations. The project is in line 
with ADB’s Energy Policy, particularly with one of its three pillars—maximizing access to energy 
for all.8 The project will add power-generation capacity and increase the reliability of electricity 
supplies in a country facing a severe power shortage. The electricity tariff for the project will not 
be susceptible to volatility of international fuel market prices, which severely impact much of the 
country’s thermal power-generation capacity. The project will promote use of indigenous and 
renewable resources, and will contribute to the country’s energy security. The project will also 
help ADB meet its annual commitment to invest at least $3 billion in clean energy, and at least $6 
billion in climate change adaptation and mitigation. 
 
14.  Lessons  from  previous  operations.  ADB  has  taken  the  lead  in  supporting  the 
government’s initiatives to attract private capital into the renewable energy sector and has been 
instrumental in pioneering many transactions, given local and international banks’ long-term 
lending constraints and reluctance to finance renewable energy initiatives. ADB led the structuring 
and financing of the country’s first three private wind power projects: Zorlu Enerji (56.4 MW) and 
Foundation Wind Energy I (50 MW) and II (50 MW) (footnote 4). ADB’s participation in these 
projects  not  only  provided  the  much-required  long-term  debt  (crucial  for  infrastructure 
development), but was also a catalyst to raise the needed equity and debt cofinancing. It also 
confirmed that investment in the wind sector is feasible and needed to ensure the country’s long-
term energy security. The project fully complements ADB sovereign operation’s support for 
energy sector reforms that target fuel mix diversification in the power sector through renewable 
energy resources.9 
 
D.  Project Cost and Financing Plan 
15.  The project is estimated to cost $360 million to be financed by debt and equity.  
 
(Confidential information redacted under para. 97(v) of ADB’s Public Communications Policy). 
 
                                                
6  ADB. 2014. Midterm Review of Strategy 2020: Meeting the Challenges of a Transforming Asia and Pacific. Manila. 
7  ADB. 2015. Country Partnership Strategy: Pakistan, 2015–2019. Manila. 
8  ADB. 2009. Energy Policy. Manila. 
9  ADB. 2006. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Multitranche 
Financing Facility and Technical Grant to Islamic Republic of Pakistan for Renewable Energy Development Sector 
Investment Program. Manila.

4       
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
(Confidential information redacted under para. 97(v) of ADB’s Public Communications Policy). 
 
F.  Projected Financial and Economic Performance 
(Confidential information redacted under para. 97(v) of ADB’s Public Communications Policy). 
 
III.  THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 
A.  The Assistance 
16.  ADB’s proposed assistance comprises a direct loan of up to $75 million from ADB’s 
ordinary capital resources. 
   
B.  Value Added by ADB Assistance 
17.  ADB’s funding is needed for this critical energy security asset, as long-term limited 
recourse dollar financing is not readily available in Pakistan’s market; international commercial 
banks are not active, and most have left the market altogether. ADB’s presence reassures STML 
and BAFL that government entities will continue to provide support throughout the project’s lives. 
STML and BAFL have been engaged with ADB since 2010 as they value ADB’s pioneering role 
and subsequent sector and development knowledge in structuring and developing Pakistan’s first 
three internationally financed wind projects. (Confidential information redacted under para. 97(v) 
of ADB’s Public Communications Policy).  ADB’s support will foster confidence among investors 
and government entities that efficiencies in renewable energy can be realized and that wind power 
can successfully achieve grid parity in line with the government’s stated objective of reducing the 
system wide generation costs from $0.12 to 0.10/kWh by 2017.10 
 
C.  Risks  
(Confidential information redacted under para. 97(v) of ADB’s Public Communications Policy). 
 
IV.  POLICY COMPLIANCE 
A.  Safeguards and Social Dimensions 
18.  In compliance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), the project is classified as 
category B for environment and C both for involuntary resettlement and indigenous peoples. The 
project’s potential environmental and social impacts have been identified, and effective measures 
to avoid, minimize, mitigate, and compensate for the adverse impacts are incorporated in the 
safeguard reports and plans. The project is located in an arid area with sparse vegetation. 
Construction-related activities are expected to have short-term impacts, with increased airborne 
dust and noise levels. Occupational health and safety risks such as exposure to excessive noise, 
vibration, work at heights, and risk of falling objects are also anticipated. Mitigation procedures 
for these are incorporated in an environmental, health, and safety manual. Based on initial 
findings, potential noise and shadow flicker impacts during operations are expected to be within 
acceptable limits, but this will be verified once project’s layout is finalized. The project is not 
expected to adversely affect the avian population, as the site is located more than 20 km from 
Keenjhar Lake, the nearest Ramsar Site wetland. Community safety risks will be minimal since 
                                                
10 Government of Pakistan. 2013. National Power Policy 2013. Islamabad.

5 
the bases of the wind turbine generators will be fenced and guarded to prevent unauthorized 
entry.  
 
19.  The cumulative impact assessment shows that the project conforms to the area’s visual 
character  since  the  government  allocated  the  wind  corridor  to  wind  farm  development. 
Environmental  management  and  monitoring  plan  implementation  during  construction  and 
operation will minimize or mitigate these impacts. Initial environmental examinations (IEEs), 
including an environmental management and monitoring plan compliant to national requirements, 
have been prepared, with approvals given by the Sindh Environmental Protection Agency. The 
IEEs will be updated to comply with the Safeguard Policy Statement, and an updated, integrated 
IEE will be disclosed on ADB website upon approval by the ADB Board of Directors. NTDC will 
conduct a detailed IEE for a 7 km transmission line. Initial findings indicate limited impacts since 
the transmission line will pass through mostly barren lands with sparse vegetation and avifauna. 
An environmental management plan will also be developed to mitigate mostly construction-related 
impacts.  TBCC  will  submit  periodic  monitoring  reports  to  ADB.  Information  disclosure  and 
consultations with affected people and land users were conducted following ADB requirements. 
TBCC will establish a grievance redress mechanism to handle project grievances. TBCC’s 
institutional capacity and commitment to manage the project’s social and environmental impacts 
are deemed adequate. 
 
20.  All wind farm components (Confidential information redacted under para. 97(v) of ADB’s 
Public Communications Policy), will be located within the leased area, which is uninhabited and 
agriculturally unproductive. A portion of the proposed wind farm has been used for opportunistic 
grazing when intermittent rain has produced edible foliage. The project will not affect these 
occasional herders as other grazing grounds are available, and the site will remain accessible to 
them  within  health  and  safety  limits.  NTDC  will  construct  the  7  km  transmission  line  on 
government land, and the line will not impact any individual or household. The project will not 
impact any indigenous peoples. 
 
21.  Other social dimensions. The project is categorized as having no gender element given 
its limited potential for gender-inclusive design. The project has no gender-specific employment 
target since it is not common in Pakistan for women to work in construction. TBCC, however, 
adheres to the principle that there will be no discrimination in recruiting project workers. During 
the peak construction period, the EPC contractor and its subcontractors will engage about 300 
workers. During operations, the number of workers will be reduced to about 35 persons. TBCC 
will ensure that its contractors and their subcontractors comply with national labor laws and, 
pursuant to ADB’s Social Protection Strategy, will take measures to comply with internationally 
recognized core labor standards.11 The borrower will be required to report regularly to ADB on (i) 
its compliance with such laws, and (ii) the measures taken to comply with such laws. TBCC will 
conduct continuous engagement with the community and consultation with affected people 
following ADB requirements. 
 
B.  Anticorruption Policy 
22.  TBCC, STML, and BAFL were advised of ADB’s policy of implementing best international 
practice relating to combating corruption, money laundering, and the financing of terrorism. ADB 
will  ensure  that  the  investment  documentation  includes  appropriate  provisions  prohibiting 
corruption, money laundering, and the financing of terrorism, and remedies for ADB in the event 
of noncompliance. 
                                                
11 ADB. 2003. Social Protection. Manila (adopted in 2001).

6       
 
C.  Investment Limitations 
23.  The proposed loan is within the medium-term, country, industry, group, and single-project 
exposure limits for nonsovereign investments. 
 
D.  Assurances 
24.  Consistent with the Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank (the Charter),12 
ADB  will proceed with the proposed assistance upon establishing that  the Government of 
Pakistan has no objection to the proposed assistance to TBCC. ADB will enter into suitable 
finance documentation, in form and substance satisfactory to ADB, following approval of the 
proposed assistance by the Board of Directors. 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
25.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the loan of up to 
$75,000,000 from ADB’s ordinary capital resources to Triconboston Consulting Corporation 
(Private) Limited for the Triconboston Wind Power Project in Pakistan, with such terms and 
conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in this report, and as may be 
reported to the Board. 
 
Takehiko Nakao 
President 
 
30 September 2016   
                                                
12 ADB. 1966. Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank. Manila.
